On 6 April 2011 04:28, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:
>
> Sometimes our view of evolution is colored by our often unquestioned
> assumption that greater complexity is a good or necessary thing. Instead,
> generally biological fitness decreases with greater complexity. A vanilla single-
> celled organism is more optimal in some reproductive sense than a human
> being. Although we have the ability to think and plan, cockroaches are more
> robust.

Hi Joel, I'll attempt to clarify my position as I don't feel like my
argument has been coloured by a 'complexity is better' bias.

The natural world has many different resources available, some are
trivially utilised like molecules or bits of food floating in the
ocean, others though are not immediately available to simple
strategies (e.g. anything you need senses and motility to get at). The
number and range of types of resources is vast and ergo so to is the
range of strategy complexity required to access them. The tendency
towards complexity then is not an innate quality of the evolutionary
process, rather it's a reflection of the complexity of the natural
world.

So taking as an example a super efficient species of bacteria floating
in the sea. These bacteria rely on passing molecules in water currents
and absorb them as they become available. One of the earliest
developments from this simple strategy was light sensitivity and
motility - one of the greatest dangers in the early history of life on
earth was UV light and it's tenedency to damage not just DNA/RNA but
just generally many organic compounds. As such some offspring started
to fit the niche whereby they detected light and where able to move to
a greater depth of water for protection. The existing non-motile
species were still around but the new species colonised a new region
of the fitness space that was previoulsy empty. The other simple
example would be fish growing legs and thus gainign access to all of
the previulsy untapped land based resources. These are just two
specific examples to make the point, but there are vastly more smaller
examples, e.g. modifications to an enzyme that allows utilisation of
some food that wasn't possible before.

This process goes all the way to humans figuring out how to use tools
and fire to access a whole new expanse of resources, ultimately (or
currently) including nuclear fission, deep sea oil reserves and the
efficiencies of collective effort made possible by language, computers
and telecommunications.

>  Whatever can reproduce does;
> different niches, even if they are suboptimal when compared to other niches, still
> accumulate.

OK so potentially I haven't gone into detail on this aspect. The
different niches are often (but not always) spacially distinct, so
e.g. a fish with legs moves on to land and has this whole new resource
available. It not longer has to compete with sharks, etc, so yes it
only has to be competetive in that niche, which initially was very
easy once you figured out how to grow legs and breath air. Each newly
complex strategy potentially put the critter in question into virgin
territory - an easy life but one that was only made possible by a new
and more complex strategy.

> However, in EC, all individuals are generally judged on the same
> scale of fitness regardless of what strategy they take. I think this is an important
> difference.

Generally, yes, but it's not an inherent quality of EC. If we were
able to simulate the natural world at the molecular level then we
would also have access to a fitness function/landscape with vast
complexity; we don't, but hopefully we can get enough complexity with
the computational resources that we do have.




> I do agree that the kinds of objectives used in EC are generally narrowly defined
> and do not offer much room for alternative strategies, which is a problem. But
> this problem may be merely a symptom of the reigning abstraction of natural
> evolution within EC, that of evolution as an optimizer.

Sure.


> That is, nearly any objective will just lead to convergence if the reward scheme
> is strictly optimizing that objective. For example, even in a simple pole-balancing
> domain, there are likely different incredibly complex and inefficient ways of
> balancing that pole -- these might be analogous to 'human-beings' within that
> domain, but we would never find them by looking for an efficient pole balancer;
> instead we might look for many different interesting (but not necessarily optimal)
> ways of balancing a pole.

No we would never find human beings in that domain, and nor should we
expect to. The essential quality of my above argument is that each
complexification allowed colonisation of a new space that couldn't be
reached with simpler strategies. If there is a simple strategy for
pole balancing then we have found a global optimum and there is
nowhere in teh fitness landscape that leads on from there. It's a dead
end. The fitness space is lacking sufficient complexity to evolve
anything more complex than the domain requires.

Note that this isn't necessarily an argument against novelty search, I
suspect that it still stands as a competetive search strategy for
certian classes of domain with the computational resource restrictions
we have.

Colin
